title: When you first heard Led Zeppelin's 'Presence' in 1976, did you immediately realize that their best days were behind them? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. Musically, what Presence offers is a collection of songs that, to me, sounds tired and therefore hard to keep focus upon. That feeling was inconceivable in their past records, even if filled with songs 20 minutes long or so. The level of emotion in Zep's music always kept me interested all the way through. We can find many reasons behind that change. Presence wasn't recorded under normal circumstances. Robert Plant had a car accident and was on a wheel chair. His voice has also changed over the years and would never get back to its early form. The band also was facing internal struggles and the very publicized alcohol and chemical abuse. Someday all that would arise to the music, and that was the time. That's not to say, however, that this is an all bad record. It has its moments - the first track, Achilles Last Stand, being the greatest of them. A fantastic song that even shows new paths for the band's sound. Something more progressive, technical but still heavy. And Robert’s voice had fit very well. All that said, I still suggest anyone to hear the record and take their own impressions. After all it's a Zeppelin record.

Let me tell you something: Presence is a damn good album. Perfect like their previous albums? No. No group can continue to produce records at that level forever. The band was going through a lot difficulty during its making. Yet they still managed to put together a quality album with a few outstanding songs: “For Your Life,” “Nobody’s Fault but Mine,” “Tea For One.” Did it have a couple clunkers? Yes. But Zeppelin B-sides are like the Beatles B-sides: still pretty good. And “In Through the Out Door?” Ditto: “In the Evening,” “Fool in the Rain,” “All My Love,” “I’m Gonna Crawl.” So it’s foolish to think 1976 was the end of their greatness. And you know what? When I reach for Zeppelin, those two albums are the first two I grab. I’ve listened to the others so many hundreds of times apiece. These days, I like to dig a little deeper, reacquainting myself with “Achilles Last Stand” over “Stairway” or “Whole Lotta Love.” My appreciation continues to grow.

By consensus, Led Zeppelin’s peak was their fourth album. However, I thought Houses of the Holy was thoroughly brilliant. No complaints - not sure which of them I’ve enjoyed the most. Led Zeppelin started their trend down hill with Physical Graffitti - although two of the sides were very much worthwhile, even those songs do not hold up to as many repeated playings as any side of their two masterpieces - or even their first three albums, probably. (Perhaps, I’m weird, but I have always found “Kasmir” to be a boring dirge with a tired worn out Robert Plant taking a crap on the song’s bridge.) Then came Presence. For my wiring and musical experiences, I have to agee with Chip Gilchrist, not Bradley Linn. It just didn’t do anything for me. However, I will agree with Bradley on In Through the Out Door - not a masterpiece, but a very fine comeback.

I didn't listen to it in 1976 because I wasn't born yet, but I went through their discography step by step and Presence is in my top 3 together with LZ 3 and Houses of the Holy. I never understood why there is so much hate for Presence, it's a hella great underrated album, I guess people are just impatient to dig deeper. I also never got why everyone thinks that LZ 4 is their peak, for me their most perfect record is third album.

Yup. I learned to play every single note on every instrument (except drums) of every single song on Zep’s first six albums. One might rightly suspect that I was a bit obsessed with their music. But they lost me after that; I didn’t hear anything new or fresh or exciting and frankly, I was greatly saddened by it.

Yes, for sure, and I think that gazzilllions Led Zep fans got the same feeling around the world. What doesnt mean we were right. Is Presence a “weak” album? By no means. It´s an amazing project. But just can´t match the previous releases, which is not a demerit. whatsoever. And their follwing and latest studio new material album, the underrated and outstanding In Through the Outdoor proved we were wrong.

When you first heard Led Zeppelin's 'Presence' in 1976, did you immediately realize that their best days were behind them? I always thought they could never top Led Zeppelin IV released in 1971 - I suspect many others felt the same.

Did your mother drop u on ur head when u qere a baby??? Achikkes Last Stand “ is a 10min masterpiece!!! Gee i wonder where Iron Maiden got their ideas when they were kids!!! All their songs are in that tune!!! They built an entire genre from it!!! “Horse gallop “ triplets !! In USA “chugging” triplets like Metallica & Godsmack plays came from that - Zep still had plenty of hits up till the end!!!!!!!!!!!! & even after they ended..on “ Coda” !!!
